7.text:
This video is all about dating, 
 but I'm definitely not dating

11.text:
this man, my mum's neighbour, 
 historian Donald Greenacres.

15.text:
So, first things first. Did the 
 caveMAN pay for dinner? What?

21.text:
how did you rate each other's

24.text:

28.text:
Donald! I'm sorry, 
 your questions are terrible.

31.text:
Well, just tell me something about 
 dating. Been here an hour.

34.text:
Well, dating as we know it didn't 
 really exist before 1700,

37.text:
unless you were poor and had 
 no wealth to protect.

40.text:
Women were essentially just traded 
 between families.

42.text:
If my mum did that to me 
 I'd key her Espace.

45.text:
In 1727 a British woman named 
 Helen Morrison wrote the first-ever

52.text: Great. And did anyone reply? Well...

64.text:
"Seeking someone nice to spend 
 the rest of my life with."

67.text:
Ooh... Well, here goes nothing, 
 Horatio.

72.text:
I doubt any man will reply, but it 
 can't make matters worse, I suppose.

82.text:
Whoever can that be? 
 Oh, you don't think...? Meow!

90.text:
Miss Morrison? 
 I'm the Mayor of Manchester. Oh, my!

97.text:
I saw your advertisement in the 
 paper, Miss Morrison.

102.text:
Ooh, why, Mr Mayor, 
 never in my wildest dreams...

106.text:
There's somewhere I'd like to take 
 you so very, very much.

111.text:
Would you accompany me? Of course. 
 I'd be delighted.

124.text:
Get in your cell! Please, I'm not 
 insane! Shut it, you lunatic!

136.text:
They locked her in a mental asylum 
 for writing a lonely-hearts ad?

139.text:
Correct. For four weeks. 
 That's horrible.

142.text:
Welcome to the treatment of women 
 through history.

148.text:
Donald, how do you date 
 a Pilgrim Father? In a bag.

152.text: It's a practice known as bundling.

154.text:

 other

156.text:
and try and, like, fart on 
 someone's head? Not quite, no.

159.text:
Believed to have started in 
 the Netherlands, it then spread

162.text:
to New England, especially amongst 
 the Pennsylvania Dutch.

165.text: Do you need me yet, Tilly?

170.text:
Just have to eat these 
 biscuits on my own.

173.text:
A young prospective couple would 
 lie in separate sacks

176.text:
so they could be in bed together 
 without getting all, erm...steamy.

181.text:
Er, like sleeping bags at 
 a sleepover?

184.text:
Yes, if the sleeping bags 
 were sewn shut and

187.text: a plank of wood placed between you.

189.text:
Is that where the expression 
 "got wood" comes from?

194.text: So before that nobody loved anyone?

198.text:
No, for most of human history it was
 believed that love would grow

201.text:
out of a marriage instead of 
 marriage out of love.

204.text:
But compatibility was still 
 considered important for conception.

208.text:
And that just...changed? 
 Not straight away.

211.text:
First, they had some very odd 
 customs.

214.text:
For instance, in 18th-century rural 
 Austria, girls would keep

218.text:
a slice of apple under their arm 
 during a dance.

240.text: I vant you to have this.

244.text:
Ohh...that's so...great. Well, 
 aren't you pleased I chose you?

249.text: Nein, nein, of course I am.

252.text:
I do, Ida, I do. Well, then, 
 eat my sveaty apple slice.

270.text:
Oh, Elbert, you DO love me. 
 You've made me the happiest...

294.text:

 the subject of dating. Right, yes.

309.text: Erm, I should think it was ham.

312.text: Uh-uh. No. It was B, spoons. Yes.

They would spend time 
 with the family
